questions.title: What Is OOP?
questions.prompt: What is Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)? What problems does it solve, and what are its core principles?
followups: Give an example from a project where OOP helped.
When might OOP be a poor fit?
How do you choose between OOP and a functional approach?

questions.title: Inheritance
questions.prompt: Explain inheritance with an example. When is inheritance useful, and when does it cause problems?
followups: What’s the difference between inheritance and composition?
How does inheritance affect testing and maintainability?
When would you prefer an interface over a base class?

questions.title: Abstraction
questions.prompt: What is abstraction? Explain how abstraction helps manage complexity in software systems.
followups: How is abstraction different from encapsulation?
Give an example of a good abstraction you’ve seen.
What are signs of a bad abstraction?

questions.title: Interfaces
questions.prompt: What is an interface? Why are interfaces useful in software design?
followups: How do interfaces improve testability?
Give an example of interface usage in real code.
What is dependency injection and how does it relate?

questions.title: Abstract Class vs Interface
questions.prompt: What is the difference between an abstract class and an interface? When would you use each?
followups: How do default implementations change the decision?
How does multiple inheritance affect this topic?
What does this look like in your favorite language?

questions.title: Exception Handling
questions.prompt: What is exception handling? How do you use exceptions responsibly in production code?
followups: When should you throw vs return an error value?
How do you avoid swallowing errors?
How do you log exceptions safely?

questions.title: Garbage Collection
questions.prompt: What is garbage collection? Explain how GC works at a high level and what trade-offs it introduces.
followups: How can GC pauses affect performance?
What is a memory leak in a GC language?
How can you reduce allocations?

questions.title: Stacks
questions.prompt: What is a stack? Explain LIFO behavior and give examples of common stack use-cases.
followups: How would you implement a stack using an array?
What’s the time complexity of push/pop?
Give an example of a stack-based interview problem.

questions.title: Queues
questions.prompt: What is a queue? Explain FIFO behavior and give examples of common queue use-cases.
followups: How would you implement a queue efficiently?
What’s the time complexity of enqueue/dequeue?
Where does a queue show up in real systems?

questions.title: Hash Tables
questions.prompt: What is a hash table (hash map)? Explain hashing, collisions, and resizing at a high level.
followups: What collision strategies do you know?
What are average vs worst-case complexities?
What makes a good hash function?

questions.title: Linked Lists
questions.prompt: What is a linked list? Compare it to an array in terms of memory layout and common operations.
followups: When are linked lists a good choice in practice?
Why are arrays often faster even when big-O looks similar?
What’s the complexity of inserting at the head vs searching?

questions.title: Big-O Notation
questions.prompt: What is Big-O notation? Explain what it captures and what it doesn’t capture.
followups: Give an example of O(n), O(n log n), and O(n^2).
Why can a worse big-O sometimes be faster in practice?
What’s the difference between average-case and worst-case complexity?

questions.title: Hash Map Insert Complexity
questions.prompt: What is the time complexity of inserting into a hash map? Explain average-case vs worst-case and why resizing matters.
followups: What triggers a resize/rehash?
How do collisions impact performance?
How would you measure this in a real program?

questions.title: What Is an API?
questions.prompt: What is an API? Explain it in simple terms and give a real example from an app you’ve used or built.
followups: What’s the difference between an API and a library?
What makes an API easy to use?
How do you version an API?

questions.title: REST
questions.prompt: What is REST? Explain REST principles and what makes an API RESTful.
followups: What are common HTTP status codes and when do you use them?
What is idempotency and why does it matter?
How do you design resource-oriented URLs?

questions.title: GET vs POST
questions.prompt: What is the difference between GET and POST? Explain use-cases and how they behave in HTTP.
followups: Which methods should be idempotent?
How do query parameters differ from request bodies?
How do caches treat GET vs POST?

questions.title: Version Control
questions.prompt: What is version control? Why is it important for software teams?
followups: What is a branch and why do we use it?
What’s the difference between merge and rebase?
How do code reviews fit into version control workflows?

questions.title: How Git Helps Teams Collaborate
questions.prompt: How does Git help teams collaborate effectively? Describe a typical workflow you’ve used (feature branches, PRs, reviews).
followups: How do you resolve merge conflicts safely?
What are good commit message practices?
How do you keep a branch up to date?

questions.title: Unit Testing
questions.prompt: What is unit testing? What makes a unit test valuable and maintainable?
followups: How do you test code that depends on external services?
What are mocks and stubs?
How do you avoid flaky tests?

questions.title: Debugging a Failing Program
questions.prompt: How do you debug a failing program? Walk through your approach step-by-step.
followups: How do you narrow down a flaky issue?
What tools do you use (logs, debugger, profiling)?
How do you prevent the issue from happening again?

questions.title: Coding Challenge You Faced
questions.prompt: Tell me about a challenge you faced while coding. What was hard, and how did you solve it?
followups: What did you learn from it?
What would you do differently next time?
How did you validate your solution?

questions.title: Handling Feedback
questions.prompt: How do you handle feedback? Share an example of feedback you received and how you acted on it.
followups: How do you respond to feedback you disagree with?
How do you ask for feedback proactively?
How do you balance speed and quality under feedback?

questions.title: Teamwork Experience
questions.prompt: Describe a time you worked in a team. What was your role, how did you collaborate, and what was the outcome?
followups: What conflict came up and how did you handle it?
How did you divide work and keep alignment?
What did you learn about teamwork?

questions.title: Why Microsoft?
questions.prompt: Why do you want to intern at Microsoft? Be specific about products, teams, or values that motivate you.
followups: What Microsoft product would you improve and why?
Tell me about a time you built something user-focused.
How do you measure impact in your work?

questions.title: What Do You Want to Learn?
questions.prompt: What do you want to learn during this internship? How will you approach learning and growth?
followups: How do you learn a new technology quickly?
How do you handle uncertainty when you’re stuck?
How do you balance learning with delivering results?

questions.title: Reverse a String
questions.prompt: Write a function that reverses a string. Explain your approach and complexity.
followups: How would you handle very large strings?
What’s the time and space complexity?
How would you reverse words instead of characters?

questions.title: Move Zeroes
questions.prompt: Given an integer array nums, move all 0s to the end while maintaining the relative order of the non-zero elements. Do this in-place.
followups: What invariants does your two-pointer method maintain?
What is the complexity?
How would you adapt this if you had to keep stable order but minimize writes?

questions.title: First Unique Character in a String
questions.prompt: Given a string s, find the first non-repeating character and return its index. If it does not exist, return -1.
followups: Why is two-pass counting useful here?
What is the time complexity?
How would you handle Unicode?

questions.title: Climbing Stairs
questions.prompt: You are climbing a staircase. It takes n steps to reach the top. Each time you can climb 1 or 2 steps. How many distinct ways can you climb to the top?
followups: Can you derive the recurrence?
How can you reduce space usage?
What is the time complexity?

questions.title: Invert Binary Tree
questions.prompt: Given the root of a binary tree, invert the tree and return its root.
followups: Can you do it iteratively?
What’s the time and space complexity?
What test cases would you use?
